sentences.sentence: After many long years a king’s son came again to that country.

He heard an old man talking about the thorn-hedge, saying that a castle( 城堡 ) was said to stand behind it in which a wonderfully( 非常 ) beautiful princess( 公主 ), named Briar Rose, had been asleep for a hundred years;
and that the King and Queen and the whole court were asleep as well.
He heard, too, that many kings’ sons had already come, and had tried to get through the thorny( 带刺的 ) hedge( 灌木丛 ), but they had remained stuck in it, and had died a terrible death.
Then the youth said, “I am not afraid, I will go and see the beautiful Briar Rose.”
The good old man tried to persuade( 劝说 ) him not to go, but the Prince( 王子 ) did not listen.
But by this time the hundred years had just passed, and the day had come when Briar Rose was to awake again.
When the King’s son came near to the thorn-hedge, it was nothing but large and beautiful flowers, which separated on their own to let him pass through unhurt, then they closed again behind him.
In the castle courtyard( 院子 ) he saw the horses and the dogs lying asleep.
On the roof( 房顶 ) sat the pigeons( 鸽子 ) with their heads under their wings.
And when he entered the house, the flies were asleep upon the wall, the cook in the kitchen was still holding out his hand to hit the boy,
and the kitchen-maid was holding the black hen which she was going to prepare for dinner.
He went on further, and in the great hall he saw the whole of the court lying asleep, and up by the throne( 王座 ) lay the King and Queen.
Then he went on still farther, and all was so quiet that a breath( 呼吸 ) could be heard, and at last he came to the tower, and opened the door into the little room where Briar Rose was sleeping.
There she lay, so beautiful that he could not turn his eyes away.
He bent( 俯身 ) down and gave her a kiss, and as soon as he kissed her, Briar Rose opened her eyes and awoke, and looked at him sweetly.
Then they went down together, and the King awoke, and the Queen, and the whole court, and looked at each other in great astonishment( 惊愕 ).
And the horses in the courtyard stood up and shook themselves;
the dogs jumped up and wagged( 摆动 ) their tails;
the pigeons upon the roof pulled out their heads from under their wings, looked round, and flew into the open country.
The flies on the wall crept( 缓慢移动 ) again;
the fire in the kitchen started burning again and cooked the meat;
the joint( 烤肉 ) began to turn, and the cook gave the boy such a hit on the ear that he screamed( 尖叫 ), and the maid( 女仆 ) plucked( 拔去（鸡或鸟的毛） ) the hen and made it ready to roast( 烤 ).
And the marriage of the King’s son with Briar Rose was celebrated with all splendor( 奢华 ), and they lived happily to the end of their days.
Rapunzel
There once lived a man and his wife, who had long wished for a child, but in vain( 徒劳地 ).
Finally, the woman started to feel that perhaps God was about to grant( 恩准 ) her desire.
Now there was at the back of their house a little window which overlooked( 俯瞰 ) a beautiful garden full of the finest vegetables and flowers.
But there was a high wall all round the garden, and no one dared( 胆敢 ) to go into it, for it belonged to( 属于 ) a powerful witch( 女巫 ) of whom all the world was afraid.
One day when the wife was standing at the window, and looking into the garden, she saw an area of earth filled with the finest rampion( 莴苣 ).
It looked so fresh and green that she began to wish for some; and the more she looked at it, the more she wanted it.
This went on for days, and as she knew she could not get the rampion, she grew pale and miserable( 难受的 ).
Then the man was uneasy, and asked, “What is the matter, dear wife?”
“Oh,” answered she, “I shall die unless I can eat some of that rampion that grows in the garden at the back of our house.”
The man, who loved her very much, thought to himself, “Rather than lose my wife I will get some rampion, no matter what( 无论什么 ) it costs.”
So in the twilight( 黄昏时分 ) he climbed over the wall into the witch’s garden, quickly picked a handful of rampion, and brought it to his wife.
She made a salad of it at once, and ate of it to her heart's content( 尽情地 ).
But she liked it so much, and it tasted so good, that the next day she wanted it three times as much as she had done before.
If she was to have any peace, the man must climb over the wall once more.
So he went in the twilight again; and as he was climbing back, he suddenly saw the witch standing before him.
He was terribly frightened( 害怕的 ), and she cried, with angry eyes,
“How dare you climb over into my garden like a thief( 小偷 ), and steal my rampion! You shall suffer( 受苦 ) for it!”

“Please,” answered he, “have mercy( 仁慈 ) on me! I only did it because I needed to. My wife saw your rampion out of the window, and wanted it so badly that she would have died if she did not get some to eat.”
Then the witch said,
“Then you may have as much rampion as you like, on one condition—the child that will come into the world must be given to me.
It shall go well with the child, and I will care for it like a mother.”
